title: Bankruptcies at lowest level since 1990 but 'debt management could skew figures'
text:
Bankruptcies at lowest level since 1990 but 'debt management could skew figures' Bankruptcies at lowest level since 1990 but 'debt management could skew figures' THE number of people going bankrupt across England and Wales has fallen to its lowest levels in a quarter of a century, official figures showed today. PUBLISHED: 17:34, Wed, Jul 29, 2015 | UPDATED: 17:47, Wed, Jul 29, 2015 GETTY Bankruptcies are falling in England and Wales 
Between April and June 3,944 bankruptcy orders were recorded, the lowest figure recorded since winter 1990, according to the Insolvency Service.The latest bankruptcy figure also represented a 27.9 per cent fall compared with the same period a year earlier.However, critics said that true extent of insolvency has been masked because of the increased number of 'debt management plans', which are not subject to registration. Last month the financial regulator found that people, who would be better off going bankrupt, have sometimes been pushed into long-term and costly plans to consolidate debts by debt management companies. Insolvency expert, Louise Brittain at accountancy firm Wilkins Kennedy, said: “There have been some changes in the landscape in the last 10 years that could play a significant part in the [bankruptcy] figures. "For example, we did not have debt management plans and the mass market of pay day loans and so while the number of formal insolvencies falling is encouraging, these statistics only show part of the picture.“Without the compulsory registration of debt management plans the true extent of the burden of debt in the UK will remain unknown.” Related articles Debt management firms blasted by regulator and told to 'clean up... 
There are three types of personal insolvency - bankruptcies, debt relief orders (DROs) that are aimed at people with lower levels of debt but no realistic prospect of paying it off, and individual voluntary arrangements (IVAs), where money is shared out between creditors.Overall, the number of people being tipped into personal insolvency in the second quarter of 2015 was found to be at its lowest levels since autumn 2005, with 18,866 cases recorded between April and June 2015.DROs, which were introduced in 2009, are likely to have affected the number of bankruptcies, the Insolvency Service said.However, there were 5,832 DROs in the second quarter of 2015, which is 16.8 per cent lower than the same period in 2014.The number of IVAs being recorded plunged by more than one third compared with a year earlier.
